context: The <a0_0>Greek<a0_0/>-speaking <b5_0>Orthodox<b5_0/> have collected <a1_0>canons and commentaries upon them<a1_0/> in a work known as the Pēdálion (Greek: Πηδάλιον, "<a2_0>Rudder<a2_0/>"), so named because it is meant to "steer" the Church. The <b6_0>Orthodox Christian<b6_0/> tradition in general treats its canons more as guidelines than as laws, the <a3_0>bishops<a3_0/> adjusting them to cultural and other local circumstances. Some <b7_0>Orthodox canon scholars<b7_0/> point out that, had <a4_0>the Ecumenical Councils<a4_0/> (which deliberated in Greek) meant for the canons to be used as laws, they would have called them nómoi/νόμοι (laws) rather than kanónes/κανόνες (rules), but almost all Orthodox conform to them. The <b8_0><b9_0>dogmatic<b8_0/> decisions<b9_0/> of the Councils, though, are to be obeyed rather than to be treated as guidelines, since they are essential for the Church's unity.
